awd_titl_txt: Working Partners: Documenting the Impact of Industry Collaboration within the ATE Community
awd_abstract_narration:
Recognizing the significant role of industry in the education and training of the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) technician workforce, the "Working Partners: Documenting the Impact of Industry Collaboration within the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Community" project investigates and identifies indicators and features of effective models of industry/community college partnerships and collaborations.  Research findings and the Working Partners Toolkit will enhance and provide know-how on creating and sustaining effective industry partnerships and collaborations with STEM technician oriented programs at two-year institutions and with secondary education programs in Career and Technical Education.  The participatory nature of the research and user oriented dissemination activities are designed to meet the information needs of a diverse body of constituents.  Project deliverables will engage policy makers and practitioners in strengthening existing partnership and collaborations and developing new types of industry/higher education partnerships and collaborations to further the global competitiveness of the STEM technician workforce.  

The scope and goals of the project are to (1) identify, investigate, and document the models of partnerships and collaboration that exist between the ATE community and industry; (2) investigate and articulate implementations, challenges, and impact of the partnership models; (3) explore and document conditions that sustain and support productive industry relationships; and (4) chronicle meaningful experiences and student academic and career pathways that arise from ATE community partnerships with industry.  The systems-based theoretical approach seeks to understand and articulate the various interdependencies and connections between people and objects in a system composed of tools, rules, overarching community expectations, and divisions of labor.  The mixed methods research design aligns the theoretical approach of the research project to the ATE program theory; couples the research questions to the research methods; structures data collection (surveys, interviews, document analysis, focus groups) and data analyses (descriptive analyses comparing emergent themes and correlations to expected patterns and correlations); and provides a conceptual framework for validating ATE/industry partnership models.

por.por_cntn:
Working Partners: Documenting the Impact of Industry Collaboration within the ATE Community is a National Science Foundation research project funded under the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program.  The ATE program puts two-year higher education institutions in a leadership role, focusing on the education of technicians for high-technology fields that drive the US economy. With an emphasis on partnerships between academic institutions and industry, the program promotes improvement in the education of science and engineering technicians at undergraduate and secondary institutions. The ATE program supports curriculum development, professional development for educators, and career pathways, along with other activities.

Effective collaborations with industry partners are a key project component for the 350 plus projects and centers in NSF?s ATE program, and to many community colleges nationwide. For more than two decades, ATE projects and centers have forged relationships with local, national, and international businesses through student internships and apprenticeships, faculty externships, industry advisory boards, and collaborative curriculum design. Robust ATE industry partnerships contribute to the overall goals of ATE by improving student success and by creating authentic workplace learning exchanges for community and technical college students and faculty.

Given the large number of existing and emerging industry/community college collaborations, surprisingly few have been studied closely. The Working Partners project aimed to fill this research void through analysis and documentation of partnership models with data about how these models have been applied in real world situations and their resulting impacts on students, faculty, institutions, and industry. The project gathered data to address key research questions and provide information to help strategically influence and guide future ATE initiatives and strengthen industry-community college partnerships both within and beyond ATE. Working Partners utilized a mixed methods approach including surveys, interviews, and focus groups.  Individual project and center data was aggregated, which generated research findings that allowed for a better understanding of the inner workings of effective community partnerships, the development of an online Toolkit, and presentations to ATE leaders and other educators seeking to build and optimize their partnerships with industry.

The results of this research included a set of eight industry-education partnership models drawn from, vetted, and refined by the ATE community,  key implementation strategies, impacts, and challenges for each model, and the creation and refinement of a Partnership Rubric which allows grantees to assess the effectiveness of their partnerships with industry over time and supports clear communication of partnership objectives and progress.  This data also provided the interesting finding that less than 5% of ATE grantees had received any sort of professional development or support to help initiate, maintain, or sustain these critical partnerships. Recognizing the gravity this gap represents for those looking to be successful in their work with industry, the team applied for and received funding from NSF to take the information gleaned from this research and transfer it into a series of workshops for grantees - taking the project from research into practice.  More information about the project may be found on the project website: https://www.workingpartnersproject.org/

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2021
Modified by: Rachael Bower
